title: 103_hr2662
content: The "Business Improvement Act of 1993" establishes business activity targets for small businesses and procurement procedures. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration must consider contracts awarded to program participants before the enactment of the Act as contracts awarded for the purpose of meeting business activity targets. Section 8 of the Small Business Act is amended to allow participating agencies to enter into contracts with small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. This includes using restricted competition or offering a price preference of up to 10%. The term "participating agency" refers to any Federal agency except the Department of Defense. The Small Business Act allows participating agencies, excluding the Department of Defense, to contract with small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals through restricted competition or a price preference of up to 10%. The authority for this provision is effective until September 30, 2000. Eligibility of past development program participants for Section 8(a) contract awards. Eligibility for Section 8(a) contract awards is amended to include small businesses owned by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals who have completed their Program Participation period. This applies to both competitive and sole source awards. Eligibility for Section 8(a) contract awards now includes small businesses owned by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals who have completed their Program Participation period. Sole source awards require the prospective awardee to be a Program Participant eligible for the contract at the time of submission. SEC. 5 amends Section 8(a)(1) of the Small Business Act by removing competitive contracts and SEC. 6 ensures continued access to business opportunities. Section 8(a)(3) of the Small Business Act is amended to require competition for contracts to furnish products or services to a participating agency if certain conditions are met. The Small Business Act is amended to require competition for contracts awarded to small businesses owned by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals who have graduated from a development program. The head of a participating agency must restrict competition for these contracts upon request from the small business concern. The Small Business Act now requires competition for contracts awarded to small businesses owned by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals. A small business concern meeting certain criteria can be eligible for a contract if they agree to subcontract a percentage of the award value to small businesses in the developmental stage of a minority small business program. The agency awarding the contract must ensure compliance with subcontracting agreements. The ownership development program requires agencies to award follow-on contracts for the same products or services to small businesses with not more than 1500 employees. A participating agency is defined as any Federal agency. SEC. 7. STUDY OF DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM PARTICIPATION TERMS BY INDUSTRY SECTOR; SUSPENSION OF DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM GRADUATIONS. The Small Business Act is amended to authorize a short-term study to determine program participation terms by industry sector for small businesses. Additionally, the suspension of development program graduations is addressed in the Act. The Small Business Act is amended to allow small business participation in programs until final regulations are issued based on industry sector study. The Small Business Act is amended to allow small businesses to participate in programs based on industry sector study or before eligibility expires. SEC. 8. COMPLIANCE WITH BUY INDIAN ACT. Federal agencies contracting with the Small Business Administration under section 8(a) for goods or services from economically disadvantaged Indian tribes are considered compliant with the Buy Indian Act. SEC. 9. UNIFORM PROCEDURES FOR CONTESTING STATUS OF CONCERNS. Section 16 of the Small Business Act is amended to establish uniform procedures for contesting the status of a concern as a 'small business concern owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals'.
